column1: # Lines starting with '#' are comments and will be ignored by the parser.
# 1. Name                    - Unique identifier for the RNase
# 2. Motif                   - Cleavage motif syntax defining where cleavage occurs (see below)
# 3. Specificity             - One of: full, semi, none, SingleN, SingleC
# To add custom RNases or override built-in definitions:
# 1. Create a TSV file with the same column format as this file
#   - If an RNase name matches an existing entry, it will be OVERWRITTEN
#   - If an RNase name is new, it will be ADDED to the dictionary
# The motif syntax uses a simple pattern language:
#   |     = Cleavage point (where the phosphodiester bond is cut)
#   G[C]| = Cleave after G, UNLESS followed by C
#          (prevents cleavage when C is 3' to G)
# RNase T1:  G|           - Cleaves after G (guanosine-specific)
# RNase A:   "C|,U|"      - Cleaves after C or U (pyrimidine-specific)
# RNase T2:  "G|,C|,A|,U|" - Cleaves after any nucleotide
# full    - Both termini must match cleavage rules
# semi    - Only one terminus must match cleavage rules
